bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, February 20, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Rodriguez Leon that he hopes to meet with her in Cuba next month. He describes a planned portrait of the conquerors of yellow fever by the Wyeth Company, and asks whether there are photographs of her father and one of his uniforms to be used in authenticating details for the painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon, February 20, 1941
div1.opener:
February 20, 1941
Mrs. Estella Rodriguez-Leon
15 St. No. 311
Vedado, Havana
Cuba
My dear Mrs. Rodriguez-Leon:
div1.p:
If my plans work out, I hope to be in Cuba the latter part of next
month for one or two weeks. I sincerely hope that you will be there and that I
may have the privilege of calling on you again. I am wondering whether I shall
be so fortunate as to be able to see some of your father's material which I believe
was packed away in your other home. I am hoping so very much that I can.

Let me write you about another but related matter. The John Wyeth Co.,
an old reputable pharmaceutical house in Philadelphia, has begun a series of fine
paintings on medical subjects. They are done by a nationally known artist and two
have already appeared, one on Dr. Beaumont and one on Dr. Osler. Thousands of copies
of each have been disseminated throughout the country and the original paintings are
being exhibited in various medical institutions. They plan to do a painting con-
cerned with the conquest of yellow fever. When I heard of this I wrote asking of
their plan hoping that I might obtain the original or an oil copy of the original
for the little museum building which I hope to see built in Havana to memorialize
Camp Lazear. The two men concerned with the development of the painting, Mr. George
Kellogg and Mr. Withington, learned that I knew some interesting data and came out
to see me. I was amazed at the detail which they have already demonstrated
in planning these paintings. They have had some difficulty in determining what kind
of uniforms your father and the other physicians wore. They also asked me if other
photographs of your father were available showing his face from several angles. It
is possible that they may write to you enlisting your help in these two points. I
know that you will want to have your father portrayed as accurately as possible. I
can assure you that I have no ulterior motive or connection with this venture except
a desire to see justice done to the members of the commission and to insure as much
historical accuracy as possible within the limits of reasonable artistic license.
Mr. Kellogg informs me that the Wyeth Co. would be delighted to defray any expenses
incident to copying some photographs of your father. They already have the convention-
al poses as published in Kelly's book. Do you by any fortunate chance still have one
of your father's uniforms? A description of it, whether it was white or khaki, and
what insignia were on the collar or shoulder strap would be very helpful information.
The preliminary sketches of the painting are in process and they hope to finish it
within the next month or two. Doubtless, you will be hearing from Mr. Kellogg but I
wanted to write you to let you know a little something about their plans.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
